STAGE.HI: [Goes to side-board and brings away the silver cup.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Very kind, upon my soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SCAT.
SP.P: Now for it — here it is. —

STAGE.HI: Putting the cup on the table.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: I say — if the 'squire was to see us play∣ing at hazard for his own plate!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SCAT.
SP.P:
Never mind — now I've once be∣gun,
I'd sooner lose all the furniture in the house than leave off: — here — I'll throw this time — [Takes the box] — Five's the main, and at all in the ring.
SP.STAGE: [As she raises her arm to throw, Old Wood∣land lays hold of it. — She lets the box fall.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Ha! ha! — look at the shepherdess now!

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: Ha! ha! — natural enough.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW. [Picking up the dice-box.]
SP.P: Look at her Ar∣cadian crook. — Oh! I said the young one would be a match for the old ones.

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: Why, 'Squire, you just came in time.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: So it seems — if I had staid ten minutes longer, I should have lost the coat off my back. — Oh, I see it all — I've been a credulous old fool, and you, Madam —

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SCAT.
SP.P: Nay, uncle, it was no fault of mine — I was decoyed by that young hypocrite —

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Decoyed by a boy! — more shame for you; and if you have no better excuse, prepare to quit my house directly — and your husband — take your fond shepherd along with you. — I've been too long a dupe to your arts; but henceforth I'll behave as a father ought to do — I'll be a friend to my son, and an enemy to all Burgundy-drinkers and faro-bankers.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Well said! — I knew my lessons would improve you — you're a fine boy; and in time I shall make a man of you — but for you, Mrs. Scat∣ter — Ha! ha! — why what a sap you must be! — at your time of life to be beat by an urchin, a child, a half-finished composition! — Upon my word, you and your fond shepherd are the two greatest flats I ever met with.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SCAT.
SP.P: For shame! What right has a boy to affect manhood?

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P:
A better right than a woman has to affect
manhood. Which is best qualified to rattle a dice∣box — a boy or a woman? — Oh, man! man! — you'd better look about you! for if children grow so experienced, and women so masculine, you'll cer∣tainly meet your deserts — be deemed a superfluity, and shoved out of the creation! — but see — yon∣der's Mr. Scatter — go, go, and console the old gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SCAT.
SP.P: I will: and he shall resent my in∣juries. — Don't fancy I'm mortified or vexed, or — no — I'm quite content—quite content! quite happy! Oh! oh! oh! [Bursts into tears.] — I'll be re∣venged, you may depend on't.

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: Hallo! — won't you take a back hand for some silver spoons?

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: And now, my little schoolmaster, how shall I thank you? to open my eyes — restore my son to me — instruct — advise! — Why, if you grow wiser as you grow older, Solomon will be a Cymon to you — but come — let's send for Tom, and all sit down to supper together.

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: So we will — get better wine, though, damme! — get better wine — treat the little hero like a gentleman. — Come along — is n't he a noble youth?

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: He is — only, he'll excuse me — were I a boy like him, I wouldn't be so fond of playing hazard and faro.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: And were I a magistrate like you, there should be no hazard or faro at all: — I'd enforce the law, and not commit one poor culprit for decoying game, till I had destroyed all those rich ones, who ensnare unsuspecting youth, and annihilate domestic happiness.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE — A Street in the Town, and View of the Sea.

SP.SPEAKER: EDWARD.
SP.P: SO — I've only to blot the story from my me∣mory— I've taken leave of Woodland; and he and Elinor will never meet again.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter SPUNGE in a travelling great coat, cap, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: What! you persist in going to Yorkshire, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: Certainly — said I'd stick to you — look — got on my travelling dress.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Your travelling dress! — I rather think it mine — Ill swear to this box great-coat.

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: So it is — it is yours: — ha! ha! — mistook it for my own.— Now it's on, I'll wear it for your sake — come — hey for Yorkshire! — this is what I like — jolly party — pleasant journey, and travelling at other people's expense.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Natural enough: — pray, Spunge, how long is it since you paid for a dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P:
How long! — let me see — oh — three years ago — remember it well — dined at the
Bedford — bill, fourteen shillings — I not one in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Well! and what did you do?

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: Borrowed a guinea of the landlord — paid my reckoning, and pocketed seven shillings by the dinner — that's the way to live cheap.

SP.SPEAKER: STELLA.
SP.P: Oh, gentlemen — if you have any pity, protect me from my guardian — I have just escaped from him — he is in pursuit of me; and if he should overtake me —

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Your guardian! — what, Mr. Scatter?

SP.SPEAKER: STELLA.
SP.P: Yes — he says, now he has lost Mr. Woodland's fortune, he has no hope but from mine; and though I some time ago accepted bills for twelve hundred pounds, which are now due and unpaid — yet he swears he'll shoot himself, if I don't sign a bond for two thousand more.

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: Two thousand pounds! — never heard of such a sum — don't believe there was ever such a sum.

SP.SPEAKER: STELLA.
SP.P: I ran out of the house; and now —

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: We'll protect you — but how to avoid your guardian? —

SP.SPEAKER: STELLA.
SP.P: Aye, there's the difficulty — I know he is in pursuit; and if he catches me — look — heavens! — there's Mrs. Scatter!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: So there is — come this way.

SP.SPEAKER: SCATTER [without.]
SP.P: You take that road — I'll take this — she can't escape then.

SP.SPEAKER: STELLA.
SP.P: There! it's all over — Oh, I'd rather live in a prison, than with such unfeeling, persecut∣ing —

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P:
Live in a prison! — faith! — that sug∣gests
a thought — did'n't you say you had accepted notes that are unpaid?

SP.SPEAKER: STELLA.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Then mind, Spunge, and do as I order you — muffle up your coat — flap your hat, and hold your handkerchief before your mouth, and keep close to Stella — I'll try if I can't be a match for them a second time.
SP.STAGE: Spunge and Stella go up the stage.]

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: Plague on the girl! — in attempting to lay hold of her, I shall be laid hold of myself — every shabby fellow I meet, I think has a writ against me — Ha! — who's here? — Oh, it's you, you little half-finished composition, is it?

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: I say, how's the shepherdess?

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: No more insolence, or, by heaven —

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: You'll put me in your pocket, and drown me in the next puddle — come, now — I'll make you amends — I will! — I'll shew you what you're looking for.

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: You!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Aye: I'll tell you where your ward is — look — [pointing her out to him] — isn't that friend∣ly?

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: It is indeed — and thus I seize her — Zounds! — what ill-looking fellow's that? —

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Come here — don't you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: No — who is he?

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: A bailiff.

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: A bailiff!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Yes: — he has arrested her for twelve hundred pounds, and has a writ against you.

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: The devil! — I'm off — yet hold — if I lose my ward —

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Lose her! — why she's safe enough, isn't she? — She's not going to Gretna Green with a lover — no — she's going to a spunging-house with a bailiff.

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: True: and there I have her snug under lock and key — why, what an amazing clever lit∣tle fellow you are!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: What! — you've found it out, have you? — why, your wife found it out last night — [Enter Mrs. SCATTER] — didn't you, shepherdess?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SCAT.
SP.P: Stand out of the way, Sir — I'm in search of — Ha! have I recovered you, Miss Stella?

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT. [taking Mrs. Scatter aside]
SP.P: Be quiet — don't you see that fellow? — he's a bailiff — has arrested her, and got a writ against me — let him take her to his house — she'll be safe enough there — you understand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SCAT.
SP.P: I do — pass on, Sir — [to Spunge] — I beg I mayn't interrupt you.

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: Civil fellow! — he ses, and don't molest me — I must reward him for his tenderness — here — give him these two guineas — they're the last of the family: — but —

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SCAT.
SP.P: Sir! —
SP.STAGE: to Spunge, offering him the two guineas.

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE. [Snatching them from her]
SP.P: Natural enough.

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: What was it he said?

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: He said it was quite enough — Ha! ha! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: Why, what are you laughing at?

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P:
I was laughing at your calling me a cle∣ver
little fellow — ha! ha! — I am one, that's the truth on't — he! he! — I say, Mr. Scatter — she's safe enough now.

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: Yes — yes — she's out of danger; and that I may be safe too, let's get out of the way as fast as we can — Come — in an hour you shall wait upon Stella—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SCAT.
SP.P: Ah! I'm afraid it's too late — our distresses are past redemption; but never mind — we're used to them — and after all, when you think of the trouble of paying and receiving money — the fatigue of keeping accounts —

SP.SPEAKER: SCAT.
SP.P: Very true: and then, when you think of the comfort of never dining without hearing duns serenading in the hall — never sleeping without knowing that there are bailiffs to protect our pro∣perty from fire and robbery — why, when you think of these luxuries, Kitty, money — money is a more troublesome commodity than you imagine.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Yes, yes: I thought you would be safer under my protection; therefore I ordered Mr. Spunge to accompany my sister — they are already set off, and now we'll follow.

SP.SPEAKER: STELLA.
SP.P: Sir Edward, what is the matter with Elinor? — when I spoke to her in the post-chaise, she seemed much dejected; and when by accident I mentioned the name of Woodland, she was so agitated —

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Indeed! — I'm glad she's gone then — she will never see him more.

SP.SPEAKER: WILLIAM.
SP.P: Oh, Sir Edward — such a misfor∣tune — your sister —

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: My sister!

SP.SPEAKER: WILLIAM.
SP.P: Passing by Mr. Woodland's park-gate, the carriage broke down, and —

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: How! — is she hurt?

SP.SPEAKER: WILLIAM.
SP.P: No — but Mr. Woodland's ser∣vants coming to our assistance, and seeing the pic∣ture — my old master's portrait in the carriage, they said — indeed, Sir — I cannot speak it.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: What did they say, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: WILLIAM.
SP.P: They said, the thief is found — charged my mistress with the robbery; and, not∣withstanding we told them she was your sister, they seized her and her companion as common malefactors, and carried them before the magistrate.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: What magistrate?

SP.SPEAKER: WILLIAM.
SP.P: Old Mr. Woodland, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: 'Tis false —'tis impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: WILLIAM.
SP.P: 'Tis too true: and if you don't go directly, Sir —

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Oh — if I forgive him this — Stella, this faithful servant will take care of you till I return — treated as a thief! — a malefactor, and by the man who betrayed — who — I can't support it — I feel I am a boy, and unequal to bear up against such complicated evils — but I forget my sister — follow me — I'm a man again.

DIV3.HEAD: An Apartment in Old WOODLAND'S House.
DIV3.STAGE:
Old WOODLAND discovered sitting in his armed Chair — Clock and Table before him — on one Side Young WOODLAND and two Servants, on the other, ELINOR, SPUNGE, and two Constables
— ELINOR is veiled, and one of the Servants holds the Picture.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Silence! — the magistrate speaks — You, Tom, swear that the picture belonged to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: I do, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: And you both swear [to servants] that you found the picture in the prisoner's pos∣session?

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANTS.
SP.P: We do, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Then bring them forward: let me have a look at them. [Elinor and Spunge are brought forward, she veiled, and he in a travelling dress.] First, who are you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: Oh, Squire! don't you know me?

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Know you!

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: Supt with you last night — drank tea with you the day before — and meant to dine with you to-morrow!

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: What! it's come home to you, is it? Oh, this is an old offender. Make out a warrant for him directly.

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: An old offender! Lord! lord! when I lived at other people's expense, little did I dream of being hanged for it! — but if you punish me, pray spare her —pray spare Sir Edward's sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: Sir Edward's sister! Sir, not for the value of the picture do I suspect them of purloining it; but from some secret, some vin∣dictive motive: and [to Old Woodland] since they persist in using and degrading an innocent lady's name, I beg they may both be committed instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir EDW. [without.]
SP.P: Where is she? where is my sister?

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: A reprieve! a reprieve!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir EDW. [who enters.]
SP.P: Does Woodland know you, Elinor?

SP.SPEAKER: ELINOR.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: So, pupil! [to Old W.] much good my lessons have done you — but I hav'n't time to finish your education — so, to school! to school, at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: I go to school?

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: To be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE
SP.P: Aye, go to school. — Adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD. [stopping him]
SP.P: Hold, Sir — where are you going?

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: What's that to you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Aye; whats that to you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: Edward, think me not un∣grateful: but I have set such a value on that pic∣ture — my hopes and fears are so involved in it — that I must beg your sister to inform me, by what strange means it came in her possession.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: She shall not answer you.

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: Not answer me!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: No — shall not. Let that suffice, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: Have a care — on any other subject I could bear much with patience: but on this — not e'en from you —

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: What! it galls you, does it?

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: You know it does. If she came fairly by the picture, there is no harm in answering the question — but if she purloined it — no matter what the motive — were she my sister — and being yours, I do esteem her as my own — I would not — nor I could not shew her mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: No — the law must take its course.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: To be sure it must — and is justice to be delayed, because she's your sister? — No; my young schoolmaster — the prisoners are found guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Prisoners, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Aye, prisoners. They are con∣victed on the evidence of my son and my servants; and were they the first people in the land, it is my duty, as an honest magistrate, to send them to prison: therefore away with them.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW. [To constables who are seizing Elinor.]
SP.P: Let her go! the fst man that touches her, dies. Hear me, Sir! hear me, you —

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: Well, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: You remember that you stole that picture.

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: Stole it!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Aye, stole it from a lady in France, Sir! — there's an act of robbery! — then you've sworn it is your own — there's an act of perjury! — then you would take away an innocent girl's life — there's an act of murder — therefore let her go — let her pursue her journey; or the rope you design for their necks shall be twisted round your own — I'll expose you — I'll expose you, Mr. Woodland!

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: Hold your licentious tongue — isn't she proved guilty of the theft?

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Theft! well, if she is — is she to suffer for purloining a piece of canvass, and you go un∣punished for stealing the dearest jewels in a woman's possession—honour, innocence, happiness?—is that law — is that justice? Look ye, Sir [to Old Wood∣land] — if you are the honest magistrate you de∣scribe yourself, let him be committed. I accuse him of the very robbery with which he charges her.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Him! — whom?

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Him — that scoundrel!

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: Scoundrel!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P:
As I wish to shew I've still some friend∣ship
for you, I wish to save you from an ignomi∣nious death. Come — follow me, and I'll be your executioner.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: You! — why, you young profli∣gate, you would not fight a man, would you?

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: No— and yet I would fight him. Come, Sir! will you come?[beckoning Young Woodland to follow him.]

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: Lead on▪ Sir — yet stay — 'tis in a sister's cause, and he is young and headstrong. I forgive you, Edward, I forgive you.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: That wo'n't do — we'll have no boys' play now [Elinor appeals to Sir Edward] — nay Elinor, when you were wronged before, I wasn't near to protect you, but now — come out, Sir! what, afraid, are you — then somebody lend me a cane, and I'll convince him I'm old enough to chastise a coward.

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: Coward! — thus, then [rushing to seize Edward] — follow me, Sir, — follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: ELINOR.
SP.P: Oh, my brother, do not terrify me — [Young Woodland breaks from his father, Elinor stops him] let me entreat you, Sir [he crosses her, she holds him] — nay then — if miss Bloomly cannot de∣tain you, perhaps Elinor Campbell can! — look! — she throws up her veil, Woodland is astonished. Oh, Woodland! if you've any pity, do not de∣prive me of the only consolation you have left me — spare but my brother, and I will kneel! — I will bless you!

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: Her brother! — the sister of my friend! — and I — Oh, villain! — villain!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Ay, look at the man now! — you call me profligate, Sir [to Old Woodland.] — no wonder if I am one, for when men set such opprobious exam∣ples, is it strange that boys grow up to infamy and ruin?

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: I see it all — this is the lady he be∣trayed in France.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: It is, Sir: and I conveyed away the pic∣ture to keep the story secret: but since it is divul∣ged — will you fight, Mr Woodland? If you've one remaining spak of friendship for him you have so injured, do pray — pray fight me. Scoundrel! —I should hit him — oh! — I know I should hit him.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Oh, Tom! Tom! — you're no son of mine — and if your mother were alive I'd tell her so to her face. Sir, — [to Edward] can an unhappy old father make you any amends?

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: None. Come, Elinor.

SP.SPEAKER: YOUNG WOOD.
SP.P: Stay — I only ask before we part for ever, that lady may be witness to my love and my remorse! — that I have wronged her my breaking heart can witness — for, from the day my uncle tore me from her — Oh! but for him, I had not known these agonies!

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Psha! — it's too late now — what motive had you for accusing her?

SP.SPEAKER: Young Wood.
SP.P: Love! — I thought that it might lead to a discovery of all I held most dear, and it has! — I see her now before me! — I once again behold her! — yet in a moment I must lose them! — for ever lose all that I prize in friendship and in love!—Oh, Edward!—you used to call me brother!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Come away, Elinor — I don't half like it — I begin to be boyish again.—He has used us both shamefully, and yet — bless me! — how miserable he looks! — poor fellow! — I don't think he'll live long! — If you've any thing to say, Elinor — Why don't you speak? — don't stand shaking here, but speak out.

SP.SPEAKER: ELINOR.
SP.P: I have nothing to say — only if his uncle caused our separation —

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: He did: and therefore—Sir!—Wood∣land!

SP.SPEAKER: Young WOOD.
SP.P: My friend!

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: I did not speak, Sir — it was my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Come—come—I see you're half inclined to forgive him, and so am I — and if you will but make me father of such a daughter, Tom shall have one-half of my estate now, and the other at my death;—and it isn't far off; for if the match takes place, I shall die with joy!— Will you — will you consent?

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: Do—love a wedding!—leads to at least one jolly party.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Well: since it must be so — there, Woodland — we are brothers in reality.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Here! — order dinner — egad! we'll have a day of it.

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: A day! we'll have a year of it! — Spread a table — lay a hundred covers—send to London for turtle, turbot, fidlers, singers, and Burgundy. Don't you trouble yourself— [to Old Woodland]—henceforward I'll be master of this house!

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Egad! — I believe yours is the best mode of living cheap after all — other peo∣ple only save by retail —

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P: And I by wholesale! — what signi∣fies saving and stinting yourself at home?—never have any home at all — live on the flats — they are always glad enough of your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Old WOOD.
SP.P: Are they?

SP.SPEAKER: SPUNGE.
SP.P:
To be sure — man and wife — Mr. and Mrs. Woodland for instance — after the honey-moon, glad when a friend pops in to in∣terrupt
the tête-à-tête—"My dear, I am so distrè" —"and I so annoyed—aw! aw!"—[yawaing]—in I come—as I shall often—very—very often.— "Ah, Spunge! glad to see you, Spunge! — stay and eat mutton, my honest fellow!" — they de∣vour my discourse — I devour their dinner — all parties are pleased;—and there's the true mode of living cheap.

SP.SPEAKER: EDW.
SP.P: Well: for your kindness to my sister, the more you honour me with your company, the happier you'll make me — this is your re∣ward!—Elinor is your's, Woodland; and you— [to Old Woodland]—in getting rid of two impos∣tors, are made happy. — But what will be my fate?—I ask not reward—I only hope to escape punishment.

Q.L: If I have been too forward and too bold,
Consider, I may mend before I'm old;
But man or boy, believe me this is true —
My chief, solt pleasure is — in pleasing you!

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.BYLINE: Written by JOHN TAYLOR, Esq SPOKEN by MISS DE CAMP.

LG.L: WELL! how d'-ye like the way of living cheap?—
What others sow with care with ease to reap.
Our friendly Bard has shewn you all the way
To share in ev'ry thing, yet nothing pay.
This Spunge is really an ingenious man—
Yet he but practices a modish plan;
Yes—he but represents a num'rous kind—
For ev'ry family its Spunge may find.
What are to them the burthens of the state!
Let grov'ling industry sustain the weight.
What is to them the mean parochial tax,
Who bear, like snails, their mansions on their backs
Should tradesmen clamour, and should writs assail,
The remedy's at hand—a friend must bail;
A friend, whose liberty is oft the price
That gives new scope to folly and to vice.
In short, at once the shifting tribe to draw,
A race of robbers, not prosrib'd by law.
Yet while our Bard would lash these men of prey,
Who live by shuffling arts from day to day;
Who, merely for some manual calling made,
Pretend to genius, and disdain a trade;
Ah! ne'er can he attempt, with wanton mirth,
To wound the man of real wit and worth;
To him, if fate the glitt'ring ore deny,
Wealth should with gen'rous pride the want supply;
For he, allur'd by fancy's dazzling rays,
Like summer myriads by the solar blaze;
Like them, too, thoughtless of the winter's cold,
The while surrounding sweets their charms unfold;
The world regarding as a transient toy,
And the true aim, the present to enjoy;
Fondly relies on Fortune's future care,
And leaves the dull her lasting gifts to share.
The lines marked thus "were not spoken. "He gives the festive board its highest zest,
"Amid the pride of rank, a nobler guest.
"In his bright noon of life caress'd by all,
"Till for new fav'rites Fashion dooms his fall.
"A chequer'd fate his waning years endure,
"Rever'd, yet slighted, fam'd, and yet obscure;
"At length distress o'erwhelms him, friendship flies,
"He droops unnotic'd, and forgotten dies!"
And now, ye moral censors, spare the play,
That strives to rout the locusts of the day.
So may the Spunges live no more on spoil,
But useful prove, and thrive by honest toil.
